text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.

-- Government is considering raising tax on corporate profits to 40 percent from some 33.3 percent, government source is quoted as saying. Well-off households may also be further targetted. (Les Echos, La Tribune, L'Agefi, Le Figaro, Liberation).
LES ECHOS

-- Former Club Mediterranee chairman Serge Trigano and co-founder Gilbert Trigano said they are leaving the company because their views on management and company style differ from those of the new chairman Philippe Bourguignon.
-- Netscape chairman Jim Barksdale says in an interview he plans to turn Internet browsing software Netscape into a supplier of Intranet solutions.
-- Semi-conductor manufacturer SGS-Thomson posts a first-half result down by fifty percent form the first half of 1996.
-- President Jacques Chirac in official visit to Belgium reaffirms committment to meeting the European single currency schedule.
LA TRIBUNE
-- La Poste may hire some 2,500 young workers.
-- Former Labour and Transports Minister Michel Delebarre chosen to assess possible plans for a partial opening of capital of France Telecom telecommunications operator.
-- MAAF and Zurich Assurances may consider bidding for insurer GAN in the event of a privatisation over which the government is negotiating with European authorities.
-- Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn said to National Assembly defence commission he was calling for an audit of the state's participation in the Dassault Rafale fighter aircraft programme.
LE FIGARO-ECONOMIE
-- An increase in taxes currently considered by the government may reach some 21 billion francs.
-- Metal workers employers' federation head Arnaud Leenhardt says in an interview a 35-hour work week would hamper employment by raising the cost of labour in France.
LIBERATION (Economic section)
-- Club Mediterranee posts a 413 million franc loss for the first half of 1997, after a 630 million francs provision.
THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
-- Outlook on taxes throws Paris bourse off stride.
